title: Bethel
text:
Bethel (, "House of <a href="El%20%28deity%29">El</a>" or "House of God", also <a href="transliteration">transliterated</a> "Beth El", "Beth-El", "Beit El"; ; ) was an ancient <a href="Israelites">Israelite</a> <a href="Sanctuary">cultic site</a> frequently mentioned in the <a href="Hebrew%20Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>.
Bethel is first referred to in the bible as being near where <a href="Abraham">Abram</a> pitched his tent. Later, Bethel is mentioned as the location where <a href="Jacob">Jacob</a> dreams of a <a href="Jacob%27s%20Ladder">ladder leading to heaven</a>, and which he therefore named Bethel, "House of God". The name is further used for a border city located between the territory of the <a href="Israelite">Israelite</a> <a href="tribe%20of%20Benjamin">tribe of Benjamin</a> and that of the <a href="tribe%20of%20Ephraim">tribe of Ephraim</a>, which first belonged to the Benjaminites and was later conquered by the Ephraimites. In the 4th century CE, <a href="Eusebius%20of%20Caesarea">Eusebius of Caesarea</a> and <a href="Jerome">Jerome</a> described Bethel as a small village that lay 12 Roman miles north of <a href="Old%20City%20%28Jerusalem%29">Jerusalem</a>, to the right or east of the road leading to <a href="Nablus">Neapolis</a>.
Most scholars identify Bethel with the modern-day village of <a href="Beitin">Beitin</a>, located in the <a href="West%20Bank">West Bank</a>, northeast of <a href="Ramallah">Ramallah</a>; few scholars prefer <a href="El-Bireh">El-Bireh</a>. In 1977, the biblical name was applied to the <a href="Israeli%20settlement">Israeli settlement</a> of <a href="Beit%20El">Beit El</a>, founded nearby. In several countries—particularly in the United States—the name has been given to various locations (see <a href="Bethel%20%28disambiguation%29">Bethel (disambiguation)</a>).
Identification.
Beitin.
<a href="Edward%20Robinson%20%28scholar%29">Edward Robinson</a> identified the Arab village of Beitin in the <a href="West%20Bank">West Bank</a> with ancient Bethel in "<a href="Biblical%20Researches%20in%20Palestine">Biblical Researches in Palestine</a>, 1838–52". He based this assessment on its fitting the location described in earlier texts, and on the philological similarities between the modern and ancient name, arguing that the replacement of the Hebrew "el" with the Arabic "in" was not unusual. Most academics continue to identify Bethel with Beitin.
El-Bireh.
David Palmer Livingston contradicts this view, based on the lack of positive identification by means of inscriptions and relying on the distance from Jerusalem according to Eusebius and Jerome. He identifies Bethel with El-Bireh, suggesting that Beitin might be biblical <a href="Ophrah">Ophrah</a>; however, Ophrah is commonly identified with the nearby village of <a href="Taybeh">Taybeh</a>.
In the Hebrew Bible.
Book of Genesis.
Bethel is mentioned several times in <a href="Book%20of%20Genesis">Genesis</a>. It is first mentioned in , as a place near where <a href="Abraham">Abram</a> stayed and built an altar on his way to Egypt and on his return. It is said to be close to the <a href="Ai%20%28Canaan%29">Ai</a> and just to the west of it. More famously it is mentioned again in , when Jacob, fleeing from the wrath of his brother <a href="Esau">Esau</a>, falls asleep on a stone and <a href="Jacob%27s%20Ladder%20%28Bible%29">dreams of a ladder</a> stretching between Heaven and Earth and thronged with <a href="angels">angels</a>; God stands at the top of the ladder, and promises Jacob the land of <a href="Canaan">Canaan</a>; when Jacob awakes he anoints the stone (<a href="baetylus">baetylus</a>) with oil and names the place Bethel. Another account, from repeats the covenant with God and the naming of the place (as El-Bethel), and makes this the site of Jacob's own change of name to Israel. Both versions state that the original name of the place was <a href="Luz">Luz</a>, a Canaanite name.
Book of Joshua.
Bethel is mentioned again in the book of as being close to <a href="Ai%20%28Bible%29">Ai</a> and on the west side of it; in this episode <a href="Joshua">Joshua</a> sent men from <a href="Tell%20es-Sultan">Jericho</a> to capture Ai. At it is again said to be next to <a href="Luz">Luz</a>, near <a href="Tell%20es-Sultan">Jericho</a>, and part of the territory of the descendants of Joseph (that is <a href="Manasseh%20%28tribal%20patriarch%29">Manasseh</a> and <a href="Ephraim">Ephraim</a>, cf. ).
Book of Judges.
In the book of the descendants of Joseph capture the city of Bethel, which again is said to have previously been called Luz. At the prophetess <a href="Deborah">Deborah</a> is said to dwell at Bethel under the palm-tree of Deborah (presumably a reference to , where another <a href="Deborah%20%28Genesis%29">Deborah</a>, the nurse of Jacob's mother <a href="Rebecca">Rebecca</a>, is said to have been buried under a tree at Bethel). Bethel is said in to be in Mt. <a href="Tribe%20of%20Ephraim">Ephraim</a>.
At , where the Hebrew Beth-El is translated in the <a href="King%20James%20Version">King James Version</a> as the 'House of God,' the people of Israel go to Bethel to ask counsel of God when they are planning to attack the Benjaminites at the <a href="battle%20of%20Gibeah">battle of Gibeah</a>. They make a second visit () after losing the battle. Bethel was evidently already an important religious centre at this time; it was so important, in fact, that the <a href="Ark%20of%20the%20Covenant">Ark of the Covenant</a> was kept there, under the care of <a href="Phinehas">Phinehas</a> the grandson of <a href="Aaron">Aaron</a> ( f). At , Bethel is said to be south of <a href="Shiloh%20%28Biblical%20city%29">Shiloh</a>.
Book of Samuel.
At the next mention of the Ark, in , it is said to be kept at Shiloh.
In the book , it is said that the prophet <a href="Samuel">Samuel</a>, who resided at <a href="Ramah%20in%20Benjamin">Ramah</a>, used to make a yearly circuit of Bethel, <a href="Gilgal">Gilgal</a> and <a href="Mizpah%20in%20Benjamin">Mizpah</a> to judge Israel. At I Samuel 10:3, Samuel tells <a href="Saul">Saul</a> to go to Bethel to visit the 'Hill of God,' where he will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place with a 'psaltery, and a tabret, and a pipe, and a harp.' It appears that there was a Philistine garrison there at that time. Bethel is mentioned again in and .
First Book of Kings.
After the kingdom of Israel was split into two kingdoms on the death of King <a href="Solomon">Solomon</a> (c.931 BC), <a href="Jeroboam">Jeroboam</a>, the first king of the northern <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Israel%20%28Samaria%29">Kingdom of Israel</a>, made two <a href="golden%20calf">golden calves</a> ( ff) and set one up in Bethel, and the other in <a href="Dan%20%28ancient%20city%29">Dan</a> in the far north of his kingdom. This was apparently to make it unnecessary for the people of Israel to have to go to Jerusalem to worship in the temple there. It seems that this action provoked the hostility of the Judaeans. A story is told at ff of how a man from <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Judah">Judah</a> visited the shrine at Bethel and prophesied that it would eventually be destroyed by <a href="Josiah">Josiah</a>.
Second Book of Kings.
According to ff, the prophets <a href="Elijah">Elijah</a> and <a href="Elisha">Elisha</a> visited Bethel on a journey from <a href="Gilgal">Gilgal</a> to Jericho shortly before Elijah was taken up to heaven alive (). Later, when Elisha returned alone to Bethel, he was taunted by some young men (not 'young boys' as it is translated in some English Bibles) as he climbed up to the shrine, and cursed them; whereupon 42 of the young men were mauled by bears ( ff).
Bethel is next mentioned in connection with the tenth king of Israel, <a href="Jehu">Jehu</a> (c. 842-815 BC). Despite his killing of the prophets of <a href="Baal">Baal</a> and destruction of their temple, it is said that Jehu continued to tolerate the presence of the golden calves in Bethel and Dan (). The shrine at Bethel apparently avoided destruction in the Assyrian invasions of the Kingdom of Israel in c. 740 and 722, but was finally completely destroyed by King <a href="Josiah">Josiah</a> of Judah (c. 640-609 BC).
Books of Ezra and Nehemiah.
Bethel is mentioned in and as being resettled at the time of the <a href="Return%20to%20Zion">return of the exiles from Babylon</a>.
Books of Amos, Hosea and Jeremiah.
The shrine is mentioned with disapproval by the prophet <a href="Amos%20%28prophet%29">Amos</a> (c. 750):
A few years later, the prophet <a href="Hosea">Hosea</a> (8th century BC) speaks (at least according to modern translations) of the "wickedness" of Bethel () and <a href="Jeremiah">Jeremiah</a> (6th century BC) speaks of the "shame" which it brought on Israel (). describes how the Israelites are abandoning <a href="Adonai">Adonai</a> for the worship of Baal, and accuses them of making or using images for 'idol' worship. Chief among these, it appears, was the image of the bull at Bethel, which by the time of Hosea was being worshipped as an image of Baal.
Archaeology.
Bronze Age.
See the excavation report by James L. Kelso (dig director 1954, 1957, 1960), <a href="William%20F.%20Albright">William F. Albright</a> (dig director 1934) and others.
Iron Age.
See the excavation report by Kelso, Albright and others.
Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine and medieval periods.
Bethel/Beitin was again inhabited and fortified by <a href="Bacchides%20%28general%29">Bacchides the Syrian</a> in the time of the <a href="Maccabees">Maccabees</a>. <a href="Josephus">Josephus</a> tells us that Bethel was captured by <a href="Vespasian">Vespasian</a>. Robinson notes that after the writings of Eusebius and Jerome, he found no further references to Bethel in the written historical record. However, he notes that the ruins at Beitin are greater than those of a village and seem to have undergone expansion after the time of Jerome, noting also the presence of what appear to be ruins of churches from the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Jerusalem">Middle Ages</a>.
